claim: The universe is expanding at an accelerating rate due to dark energy.
paraphrase: Dark energy is causing the expansion of the cosmos to speed up.
contradiction: The universe is contracting at a decelerating rate due to dark energy.

claim: The Big Bang marks the hot, dense origin of the observable universe.
paraphrase: The Big Bang describes the early hot and dense state from which the universe expanded.
contradiction: The Big Bang describes a cold, static origin of the universe with no expansion.

claim: Cosmic inflation is a brief period of extremely rapid expansion in the early universe.
paraphrase: Early in cosmic history the universe underwent a very short, rapid inflationary expansion.
contradiction: Cosmic inflation describes a slow and steady contraction early in the universe.

claim: The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is leftover radiation from the early universe.
paraphrase: The CMB is the remnant glow of radiation left over from the early stages after the Big Bang.
contradiction: The CMB is radiation emitted only by current stars in our galaxy.

claim: Dark matter interacts primarily via gravity and is not directly visible.
paraphrase: Most evidence shows dark matter affects visible matter through gravity while being invisible to light.
contradiction: Dark matter emits strong visible light and can be easily seen in telescopes.

claim: The Hubble-Lemaître law states galaxy recessional velocity is proportional to distance.
paraphrase: Galaxies farther away recede faster, proportional to their distance (Hubble's law).
contradiction: Hubble's law states that galaxies closer to us recede faster than distant galaxies.

claim: The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy.
paraphrase: Our galaxy, the Milky Way, has a central bar and spiral arms.
contradiction: The Milky Way is an elliptical galaxy with no spiral arms.

claim: Elliptical galaxies generally contain older, redder stars and less gas than spirals.
paraphrase: Elliptical galaxies typically have older stellar populations and little cold gas for star formation.
contradiction: Elliptical galaxies have more young blue stars and abundant star-forming gas than spiral galaxies.

claim: A star's position on the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram depends primarily on its temperature and luminosity.
paraphrase: Temperature and brightness determine a star's placement on the HR diagram.
contradiction: A star's HR diagram position depends only on its distance to Earth.

claim: Massive stars end their lives as supernovae and can leave behind neutron stars or black holes.
paraphrase: When very massive stars explode as supernovae, their cores may become neutron stars or black holes.
contradiction: Massive stars always become planets after they die.

claim: Our Sun is currently a main-sequence G-type star.
paraphrase: The Sun is a G-class star on the main sequence, fusing hydrogen into helium.
contradiction: The Sun is a red giant that no longer fuses hydrogen.

claim: White dwarfs are stellar remnants supported by electron degeneracy pressure.
paraphrase: Electron degeneracy pressure prevents collapse in white dwarfs, which are dead stellar cores.
contradiction: White dwarfs are sustained by ongoing nuclear fusion in their cores.

claim: A neutron star is composed mostly of neutrons and has extremely high density.
paraphrase: Neutron stars are incredibly dense objects mainly made of neutrons after a core-collapse supernova.
contradiction: Neutron stars are diffuse gas clouds with very low density.

claim: Black holes have an event horizon beyond which nothing can escape, not even light.
paraphrase: The event horizon of a black hole is the boundary past which escape is impossible for light and matter.
contradiction: Black holes have no horizon and light freely escapes from their centers.

claim: Gravitational waves are ripples in spacetime predicted by general relativity.
paraphrase: Einstein's general relativity predicts gravitational waves that propagate through spacetime.
contradiction: Gravitational waves are static distortions that do not propagate.

claim: Frame-dragging is an effect where a rotating mass twists nearby spacetime.
paraphrase: A rotating object can drag spacetime around it, an effect predicted by general relativity.
contradiction: Rotation of mass has no influence on the surrounding spacetime.

claim: The Solar System formed roughly 4.6 billion years ago from a protoplanetary disk.
paraphrase: About 4.6 billion years ago the planets formed from a disk of gas and dust around the young Sun.
contradiction: The Solar System formed less than one million years ago.

claim: Jupiter is the largest planet in our Solar System by mass and volume.
paraphrase: No planet in the Solar System exceeds Jupiter in size or mass.
contradiction: Mercury is the largest planet in the Solar System.

claim: The Kuiper Belt lies beyond Neptune and contains many icy minor bodies.
paraphrase: Beyond Neptune is the Kuiper Belt, home to numerous icy objects and dwarf planets.
contradiction: The Kuiper Belt is located between Mars and Jupiter and is full of gas giants.

claim: The Oort Cloud is a remote spherical shell of icy bodies surrounding the Solar System.
paraphrase: Cometary bodies in a distant spherical Oort Cloud populate the outermost Solar System.
contradiction: The Oort Cloud is a dense ring of lava planets orbiting close to the Sun.

claim: Titan, a moon of Saturn, has a thick atmosphere rich in nitrogen and hydrocarbon lakes.
paraphrase: Saturn's moon Titan has a dense nitrogen atmosphere and surface lakes of hydrocarbons.
contradiction: Titan has no atmosphere and a dry, rocky surface like the Moon.

claim: Mercury has virtually no atmosphere and experiences extreme temperature variations.
paraphrase: Because Mercury lacks a substantial atmosphere, it faces very hot days and very cold nights.
contradiction: Mercury has a thick, protective atmosphere moderating its surface temperature.

claim: Venus has a runaway greenhouse effect making its surface extremely hot.
paraphrase: A thick CO₂ atmosphere causes Venus to have very high surface temperatures through greenhouse warming.
contradiction: Venus is cold at the surface due to a thin atmosphere.

claim: The greenhouse effect on Earth warms the planet by trapping infrared radiation.
paraphrase: Greenhouse gases absorb infrared radiation and help keep Earth's surface warmer than it would be otherwise.
contradiction: Greenhouse gases cool Earth by letting more heat escape to space.

claim: Mars has a thin CO₂ atmosphere and evidence of past water activity.
paraphrase: Mars' atmosphere is thin and predominantly CO₂, and geological evidence suggests there was once liquid water.
contradiction: Mars has a thick oxygen-rich atmosphere and abundant liquid oceans today.

claim: Kepler's laws describe planetary motion: elliptical orbits with the Sun at a focus.
paraphrase: Kepler formulated laws stating planets orbit in ellipses, sweep equal areas in equal times, and have period-distance relations.
contradiction: Kepler's laws claim planets travel in perfect circles at constant speed with the Sun at the center.

claim: Escape velocity is the speed needed to break free from a body's gravity without further propulsion.
paraphrase: A spacecraft must reach escape velocity to leave a planet's gravitational influence without more thrust.
contradiction: Escape velocity is irrelevant; any speed will let you escape gravity without additional forces.

claim: Tidal locking occurs when a body's rotation period matches its orbital period around its primary.
paraphrase: When a moon is tidally locked, the same face always points toward its planet due to synchronized rotation and orbit.
contradiction: Tidal locking causes a moon to rotate rapidly so all its faces see the planet equally.

claim: The Roche limit defines the distance within which a celestial body will be tidally disrupted by its planet.
paraphrase: If a moon orbits closer than the Roche limit, tidal forces can tear it apart into rings.
contradiction: The Roche limit indicates where satellites are perfectly safe from tidal forces and will never break apart.

claim: Astronomical spectroscopy reveals chemical compositions and velocities via spectral lines.
paraphrase: By analyzing spectral lines, astronomers infer an object's elements and motion through Doppler shifts.
contradiction: Spectroscopy can only measure object brightness, not composition or motion.

claim: Redshift of distant galaxies indicates they are receding from us.
paraphrase: Galaxies shifted toward red wavelengths show they are moving away, consistent with cosmic expansion.
contradiction: Redshift proves galaxies are moving toward us at high speed.

claim: The Doppler effect causes spectral lines to shift depending on radial velocity.
paraphrase: If an object moves toward or away, its spectral lines shift in wavelength due to Doppler motion.
contradiction: The Doppler effect randomly changes spectral lines regardless of motion.

claim: An exoplanet in the habitable zone could potentially host liquid water on its surface.
paraphrase: Planets within a star's habitable zone may have conditions suitable for liquid water.
contradiction: Planets in the habitable zone are always barren and never have liquid water.

claim: Transit photometry detects exoplanets by measuring dips in a star's brightness.
paraphrase: When a planet transits its star, the resulting brightness dip can reveal its presence and size.
contradiction: Transit photometry detects planets by measuring changes in the star's color, not brightness.

claim: Radial velocity detects exoplanets via the star's wobble caused by the planet's gravity.
paraphrase: Planet-induced stellar wobble produces Doppler shifts that radial velocity measurements detect.
contradiction: Radial velocity methods rely on direct imaging of the planet rather than stellar motion.

claim: Gamma-ray bursts are extremely energetic explosions observed in distant galaxies.
paraphrase: GRBs are brief but very powerful extragalactic explosions detectable in gamma rays.
contradiction: Gamma-ray bursts are weak radio signals that occur only within our Solar System.

claim: Type Ia supernovae are used as standard candles to measure cosmic distances.
paraphrase: Because type Ia supernovae have consistent peak brightness, astronomers use them to estimate distances.
contradiction: Type Ia supernovae have wildly varying intrinsic brightness and cannot be used for distance measurements.

claim: Active galactic nuclei (AGN) are luminous centers of galaxies powered by accreting supermassive black holes.
paraphrase: Many galaxies host AGN where material falling into a supermassive black hole produces extreme luminosity.
contradiction: AGN are cold, dark regions with no accretion or high energy emission.

claim: Pulsars are rotating neutron stars that emit regular pulses of radiation.
paraphrase: A pulsar's lighthouse-like beams sweep past Earth, producing regular pulses as it spins.
contradiction: Pulsars emit continuous unmodulated light with no pulsed signal.

claim: Magnetars are neutron stars with extremely strong magnetic fields that power bursts.
paraphrase: Very strong magnetic fields in magnetars can drive energetic X-ray and gamma-ray flares.
contradiction: Magnetars have weak magnetic fields and never produce violent bursts.

claim: Molecular clouds are cold, dense regions where stars form.
paraphrase: Stars commonly form inside dense, cold molecular clouds composed of gas and dust.
contradiction: Stars form in hot, diffuse regions with no molecular gas or dust.

claim: Accretion disks form around young stars and compact objects due to angular momentum conservation.
paraphrase: Material spirals into objects forming a flattened accretion disk because angular momentum must be conserved.
contradiction: Accretion disks form spontaneously without any relation to angular momentum.

claim: Adaptive optics compensates for atmospheric distortion to sharpen ground-based images.
paraphrase: Ground telescopes use adaptive optics systems to correct atmospheric blurring in real time.
contradiction: Adaptive optics intentionally blurs images further to reduce resolution.

claim: Radio telescopes observe long-wavelength radio emission from celestial sources.
paraphrase: Astronomers use radio telescopes to detect low-frequency radio waves from space.
contradiction: Radio telescopes are only used to detect visible light from stars.

claim: The speed of light in vacuum is a fundamental constant approximately 299,792 km/s.
paraphrase: Light travels through empty space at about 299,792 kilometers per second, a universal constant.
contradiction: Light speed in vacuum varies dramatically with the observer and is not constant.

claim: Cosmic rays are high-energy particles originating from space that strike Earth's atmosphere.
paraphrase: High-energy particles called cosmic rays impact Earth's atmosphere and create cascades of secondary particles.
contradiction: Cosmic rays are harmless photons produced only within Earth's oceans.

claim: Gravitational lensing bends light around massive objects, producing multiple or distorted images.
paraphrase: Massive foreground objects can act like lenses and distort or multiply background source images.
contradiction: Gravitational lensing makes distant galaxies invisible by absorbing all their light.

claim: Voyager 1 has entered interstellar space and continues to send data back to Earth.
paraphrase: Voyager 1 crossed the heliopause into interstellar space and still communicates with Earth.
contradiction: Voyager 1 is currently orbiting Jupiter and remains within the planet's magnetosphere.

claim: The Apollo missions landed humans on the Moon between 1969 and 1972.
paraphrase: NASA's Apollo program conducted crewed lunar landings from 1969 through 1972.
contradiction: The Apollo missions never landed humans on the Moon; all landings occurred after 2000.

claim: The habitable zone depends on the star's luminosity and the planet's distance.
paraphrase: A star's brightness and the orbital distance determine where liquid water may exist on a planet.
contradiction: Habitable zones are the same size around all stars regardless of luminosity.

claim: The Drake Equation is a probabilistic estimate for the number of communicative civilizations in the galaxy.
paraphrase: Drake's equation multiplies astrophysical and biological factors to estimate the number of detectable civilizations.
contradiction: The Drake Equation proves the exact number of alien civilizations on Earth.

claim: Saturn's rings are composed of ice and rock particles ranging from dust to meters in size.
paraphrase: Particles made of ice and rock, from small grains to large chunks, make up Saturn's rings.
contradiction: Saturn's rings are solid continuous shells of metal surrounding the planet.

claim: Comets are icy bodies that develop comas and tails when approaching the Sun.
paraphrase: When heated by the Sun, cometary ices sublimate creating visible comas and tails.
contradiction: Comets never develop tails and remain inert when they approach the Sun.

claim: Earth's magnetic field protects the atmosphere by deflecting charged solar particles.
paraphrase: The magnetosphere shields Earth's atmosphere from many charged particles from the Sun.
contradiction: Earth's magnetic field amplifies solar wind, rapidly stripping the atmosphere.

claim: Aurorae form when charged solar particles collide with atmospheric atoms near the poles.
paraphrase: Polar auroras result from solar particles exciting atoms in Earth's upper atmosphere.
contradiction: Aurorae form due to tectonic plate movement near the equator.

claim: Brown dwarfs are substellar objects not massive enough to sustain hydrogen fusion.
paraphrase: A brown dwarf lacks sufficient mass for stable hydrogen fusion like true stars.
contradiction: Brown dwarfs are massive stars that sustain prolonged hydrogen fusion like the Sun.

claim: Spectral classification of stars (OBAFGKM) orders them roughly by temperature.
paraphrase: Stars are classified from hottest to coolest by spectral type O, B, A, F, G, K, M.
contradiction: Spectral types list stars from coldest to hottest with M first and O last.

claim: Planetary migration can move planets inward or outward during early system evolution.
paraphrase: Interactions in the protoplanetary disk can cause planets to change their orbital distances over time.
contradiction: Planets always remain at the exact orbital distance where they formed and never migrate.

claim: Mean motion resonances can lock orbital periods into integer ratios (e.g., 2:1 resonance).
paraphrase: Resonances occur when orbital periods form simple integer ratios, stabilizing interactions.
contradiction: Orbital resonances force all bodies to have identical orbital periods.

claim: The heliopause is the boundary where the solar wind pressure balances the interstellar medium.
paraphrase: At the heliopause, the influence of the Sun's solar wind ends and interstellar space begins.
contradiction: The heliopause is the center of the Sun where solar wind is generated.

claim: Enceladus shoots plumes of water ice into space from its south pole.
paraphrase: Geysers on Enceladus eject icy particles from a subsurface ocean.
contradiction: Enceladus is a dry, cratered moon with no geological activity.
